story.title: HotKey Product Launch
story.description: Built HotKey - a Chrome extension that captures AI chat wins and generates social posts in 30 seconds. One hotkey (Cmd+L) captures context, AI generates platform-ready posts (Twitter/LinkedIn/Instagram), email notification for review. $29/month, no free tier. 4-week timeline to launch. formats.name: Twitter
formats.content:
Built something for myself that I think you'll want.

**The problem:** I'm constantly having wins in ChatGPT/Claude chats. Figure out a clever architecture. Debug a tricky problem. Ship a feature. But I don't capture them because switching to Twitter breaks flow.

So they die in chat history.

**The fix:** HotKey. One hotkey (Cmd+L) while working:
â€¢ Captures what just happened
â€¢ Generates 3 platform-ready posts (Twitter/LinkedIn/Instagram)
â€¢ Emails you a review link
â€¢ Copy-paste to publish

30 seconds. No app-switching. No "I'll post about this later" (you won't).

**The business model:** $29/month, no free tier. Why? AI costs are real ($3/user/month), and free tiers attract people who won't use it. I want serious users building in public, not tire-kickers.

**Current status:** Review UI is live and working. Chrome extension starts next week. 4-week timeline to launch.

Pre-selling on Twitter first. If 10+ people want early access, I'm building it.

This is the difference between people who build in public and people who *want* to. Removing the friction.

formats.name: LinkedIn Article
formats.content:
**The "building in public" friction problem**

I just finalized the MVP for HotKey - a Chrome extension that captures your AI chat wins and turns them into social posts in 30 seconds.

Here's why I'm building it:

**The Reality:**
Every day, white-collar AI workers (developers, founders, consultants) have genuinely interesting wins:
â€¢ Solve a tricky architecture problem
â€¢ Debug something clever
â€¢ Ship a feature that took 30 minutes instead of 3 hours

These are great content moments. But they don't get shared because the friction is too high.

You'd have to:
1. Stop what you're doing
2. Screenshot the chat
3. Open Twitter/LinkedIn
4. Remember what was interesting
5. Write the post
6. Format it for the platform

By the time you finish, you've lost 10 minutes and broken your flow. So you don't do it.

**The Solution:**
HotKey removes the friction:
â€¢ Hit Cmd+L while working in ChatGPT/Claude
â€¢ System captures context + screenshot
â€¢ AI generates 3 platform-specific drafts (Twitter, LinkedIn, Instagram)
â€¢ Email notification with review link
â€¢ Copy-paste to publish

30 seconds total. Zero app-switching.

**Product Decisions:**

**$29/month subscription (no free tier)**
Why? AI costs are $3/user/month. A free tier would attract people who won't use it. I want serious users building in public, not people collecting tools.

**Chrome extension MVP (not native app)**
Why? Works everywhere (ChatGPT, Claude, OpenClaw web). iOS app is Phase 2.

**Copy-paste workflow (not auto-posting)**
Why? User stays in control. Auto-posting adds complexity and trust issues. Manual copy-paste is fast enough and keeps the user in the loop.

**Timeline:**
â€¢ Review UI: âœ… Done (v1.0.0 live)
â€¢ Chrome extension: Week 1-2
â€¢ API + email notifications: Week 3
â€¢ Beta launch: Week 4

**Pre-sell validation:**
Before building the extension, I'm pre-selling on Twitter. If 10+ people want early access, it's a signal there's real demand.

This is the difference between people who successfully build in public and people who *want* to build in public but never do.

The friction kills the habit before it starts.

story.title: Content Hook Optimization System
story.description: My content system was generating boring posts. Took a step back and realized why: I was doing text manipulation instead of understanding what actually makes content viral. Analyzed hundreds of viral posts across platforms. Posts with strong hooks vs weak hooks showed up to 40x difference in engagement. Built complete hook optimization system (HOOK-OPTIMIZATION.md and HOOK-COMPARISON.md). Now building AI that understands hook psychology first, then crafts the story around it.

formats.name: Twitter
formats.content:
1/ My content system was generating boring posts. Took a step back and realized why: I was doing text manipulation instead of understanding what actually makes content viral.

2/ So I went deep on research. Analyzed hundreds of viral posts across platforms. The pattern was clear: it's not about the story you're tellingâ€”it's about the hook you lead with.

3/ Found some wild stuff in the data. Posts with strong hooks vs weak hooks? Research shows up to 40x difference in engagement. Same story, different hook = completely different results.

4/ The insight hit me: content quality = hook quality. Your story is just raw material. Each platform needs to interpret that story through proven hook patterns.

5/ Built a complete hook optimization system. Created HOOK-OPTIMIZATION.md and HOOK-COMPARISON.md to document everything. Not just theoryâ€”actual patterns that work.

6/ Now instead of manipulating text, I'm building AI that understands hook psychology first, then crafts the story around it. Research phase, but the system is taking shape.

7/ Building @HotKeyAI in public. If you're interested in AI content systems that actually understand engagement patterns, follow along. This is just the beginning.

formats.name: LinkedIn Article
formats.content:
Brutal honesty: My AI content system was generating boring posts.

I'd built this whole system using text manipulation, thinking I was clever. But the posts fell flat. Low engagement, no viral moments. Classic case of solving the wrong problem.

So I went back to basics and researched what actually makes content viral. Spent weeks analyzing patterns across platforms, documenting everything in HOOK-OPTIMIZATION.md and HOOK-COMPARISON.md.

The research revealed something striking: posts with strong hooks vs weak hooks showed up to 40x difference in engagement. Same exact story, different opening line = completely different trajectory.

Key insight: Content quality equals hook quality. Your story is just raw materialâ€”each platform interprets it differently using proven psychological patterns.

Instead of text manipulation, I'm now building AI that understands hook psychology first, then crafts the story around it. Not claiming magic results yetâ€”this is honest research phase building.

But the system architecture is solid. When you study what works at scale, patterns emerge. Now it's about encoding those patterns into something that can replicate the process.

What's your experience with content hooks? Do you lead with the story or the psychology?
